column1: Surabaya (Indonesian pronunciation: [suraˈbaja] (listen); older spelling: Soerabaja) is the capital of the Indonesian province of East Java and the third-largest city in the country
column2: after Jakarta and Bekasi. The city has a population of 2.89 million within its city limits in 2019 and 9.5 million in the extended Surabaya metropolitan area
column3: making it the third-largest metropolitan area in Indonesia. Located on northeastern border of Java island
column4: on the Madura Strait
column5: it is one of the earliest port cities in Southeast Asia. According to the National Development Planning Agency

column2: in which it was called Jung-ya-lu. The name Janggala was probably originated from the name "Hujung Galuh" (Old Javanese lit: "Cape Diamond" or "Cape Gemstone")
column3: or "Jung-ya-lu" according to Chinese source. Hujung Galuh was located on the estuarine of Brantas River and today is the part of modern Surabaya city and Sidoarjo Regency.

column12: Surabaya was the largest city in the Dutch East Indies. It became a major trading center under the Dutch colonial government and hosted the most extensive naval base in the colony. Surabaya was also the largest city in the colony serving as the center of Java's plantation economy

column5: who had become caretakers of the Dutch colony after the Japanese surrender.The Battle of Surabaya
column6: one of the well-known battles of the Indonesian revolution
column7: started after the Arek-Arek Suroboyo (Teenagers of Surabaya) assassinated the British Brigadier Mallaby on 30 October 1945

The incident of the red-white flag (the Dutch flag at the top of Yamato Hotel's tower that was torn into the Indonesian red-white flag) by Bung Tomo is also recorded as a heroic feat during the struggle of this city.The city is known as Kota Pahlawan  (the city of heroes) due to the importance of the Battle of Surabaya in galvanising Indonesian and international support for Indonesian independence during the Indonesian National Revolution.

column1: Under the Köppen climate classification system
column2: Surabaya features a tropical wet and dry climate (Aw)
column3: with distinct wet and dry seasons. The city's wet season runs from November through June
column4: while the dry season covers the remaining four months. Unlike many cities and regions with a tropical wet and dry climate

column6: with an average high temperature of around 31 °C and average low temperatures around 23 °C.

column1: Surabaya is one of the cleanest and greenest cities in Indonesia. This can be seen by the urban parks in almost every neighborhood area which is equipped with fountains. These parks include Bungkul Park

column18: and other green awards. The Adipura Cup
column19: which Surabaya won several times in the 1980s and 1990s
column21: the cleanest metropolitan city category in the 1990s and in the period of 2010 to 2017
column23: as well as the Adipura trophy
column24: plenary in 2016. The city also received several awards from the central government as one of the major cities with the best air quality in Indonesia. Surabaya in 2012 has won the award "City of the Best Participation in the Asia Pacific" by Citynet for the success of the city government and people's participation in managing the environment. Surabaya has also been awarded the ASEAN Environmentally Sustainable City Award or "the city with the best sustainable environmental management in ASEAN" in 2011 and 2014. In 2018

column31: especially in the neighborhoods of Southern and Northern Surabaya. This is the concern of the city government to reorganise the environment of the region.

column2: a subdialect of the Arekan dialect. A stereotype of this dialect concerns equality and directness in speech. The use of register is less strict than the Central Java dialect. The Suroboyoan dialect is a mixture of both Indonesian and Javanese

His tomb is a sacred religious site in the city and is visited by Surabayans and pilgrims from different parts of Indonesia. The largest Muslim organisation in Indonesia

column14: a branch of native Christianity. Around 15 churches are in Surabaya; they vary in size. The Church of the Birth of Our Lady

column1: Another prevalent sport is badminton. There are numerous schools and clubs in the city that train students of various ages to reach the next level of the Badminton League. Many children start out their career from Surabaya and have made it to the national and sometimes international level.
